column5: When comparing all men and women who work full time::: year round in Mississippi::: women are paid just 75 cents for every dollar paid to their male counterparts. But the wage gap experienced by women of color in Mississippi is even larger. Black women are paid just 56 cents for every dollar paid to white::: non-Hispanic men. Latinas and Native women are paid just 60 cents and 55 cents::: respectively::: for every dollar paid to white::: Non-Hispanic men. And Asian women are paid just 66 cents on the dollar.

column3: Congrats to the grads and HAPPY BIRTHDAY MISSISISPPI! Mississippi became the 20th state on Dec. 10::: 1817.  MEET MY MISSISSIPPI William Faulkner's Sanctuary Eudora Welty's home state Elvis Presley's birthplace The bulk of the Natchez Trace; Choctaw Nation native land Rolling hills of the Chickasaw Band Sprawling beaches along the Gulf Coast shore One blues man::: Robert Johnson's::: Crossroads and inspiration for more; Like Albert::: B.B.::: Bukka::: Charley Patton ::: Howlin' Wolf ::: Little Milton and Muddy Waters who came to the fore There's farm raised catfish ::: Delta tamales ::: Vardaman sweet potatoes ::: seafood galore And warm front porch welcomes with a wide open door Creative muse for Barq's::: Stetson::: Peavey::: Viking And Henson's famous green frog And "Where The Southern Crosses The Yellow Dog " An abundance of history::: tradition and folklore With Ruins of Windsor::: Vicksburg Battlefield Emerald Mound ::: Grand Village::: Ingomar :::Winterville and Pharr Mounds to explore You'll find an authentic Dentzel carousel merry go round Where Jimmie Rodgers ::: "The Singing Brakeman' fathered a unique country sound Conway Twitty::: Charley Pride:::Tammy Wynette and Marty Stuart all came down the line Along with Bobbie Gentry ::: Faith Hill:::and young LeAnn Rimes She's the place where Coca Cola was bottled for the very first time And Pine-Sol invented to combat dirt and grime Fred Smith::: a Mississippi native::: few would guess::: Was the innovative mastermind behind Federal Express. The first heart transplant and first lung transplant were performed right here Where Dr. James Hardy stepped in::: when others had fear. For football legends::: you don't have to think twice::: There's Brett Favre :::Archie Manning::::::Walter Payton and Jerry Rice. More Mississippi greats ::: amazingly::: include Jerry Clower::: Ruby Elzy::: Medgar Evers ::: Morgan Freeman::: John Grisham ::: Fannie Lou Hamer::: James Earl Jones::: James Meredith ::: Anne Moody ::: Willie Morris and Leontyne Price Along with Sela Ward ::: Margaret Walker::: Ida B Wells ::: Tennessee Williams::: Mary Wilson::: Oprah Winfrey::: and author Richard Wright To name all of them::: time would never suffice She's a ride down the Mighty River on the American Queen And some of the most beautiful countryside that you've ever seen She's music and melodies and the mockingbird's songs::: By valor and arms and faith ever strong; She's magnolias blooming around Jackson's capitol dome With the buzz of the honeybee And sweet scent of the honeysuckle That forever say "home" She's a land of cotton Where the white tailed deer roam Since December 10::: 1817 Our 20th state "Go Mississippi " The Hospitality State Roll On Mississippi You're a true State of Grace. by Patricia Neely-Dorsey Help Promote a Positive Mississippi ! PLEASE SHARE! #Mississippi

column10: When comparing all men and women who work full time::: year round in Mississippi::: women are paid just 75 cents for every dollar paid to their male counterparts. But the wage gap experienced by women of color in Mississippi is even larger. Black women are paid just 56 cents for every dollar paid to white::: non-Hispanic men. Latinas and Native women are paid just 60 cents and 55 cents::: respectively::: for every dollar paid to white::: Non-Hispanic men. And Asian women are paid just 66 cents on the dollar.

column1: â€œThe experience at Mississippi State that has helped me grow the most is being part of MSUâ€™s Athlete Engineering team. Iâ€™m the graduate student lead for the report automation taskforce::: and we support athletic coaches by creating or automating reports using data from their wearable technology and generally assisting them with their other devices in any way we can. Depending on the device and the number of athletes who use it::: the amount of data collected can be overwhelming. We try to distill the data into insightful and easily digestible visuals so that coaches can translate what's important into action during practices or live games. Whatâ€™s important is using the data to tell a story. Iâ€™m grateful to this program for exposing me to a high-functioning::: interdisciplinary team. Dr. Reuben Burch::: an assistant professor of industrial and systems engineering who helped create MSUâ€™s athlete engineering program::: has been such a strong supporter for me::: helping me grow in both knowledge and confidence.â€  Sam Osborne::: Industrial and Systems Engineering::: Graduate Student #MSUExperience

column1: "Every day::: Iâ€™m here solely to help our veterans. When I joined the Marines::: I was stationed in Hawaii and served two tours in Iraq and Afghanistan. I know firsthand how difficult it can be to get back on your feet as a veteran::: so I want to do everything I can to help them. I serve as the Veterans Service Officer for the Mississippi VA here at MSUâ€™s Center for Americaâ€™s Veterans and am grateful to be a student here in the process. Iâ€™m studying public policy and administration::: which correlates with my bachelorâ€™s degree in diplomacy & military studies from Hawaii Pacific University. Military officers were the first public administrators::: and Iâ€™ve learned a great deal about government and policy through this masterâ€™s degree program already. I believe it will help me with my current job and advance my career in the future.â€  Ridge Blackburn::: Public Policy and Administration::: Graduate #MSUExperience  (Photo by Megan Bean / OPA)

column13: When I was a student::: I remember going there as a child with my parents after church. My parents got food upstairs but I went through the kitchen to the stairs and went downstairs to the grill. I waited outside the railing until the cook spotted me and fixied me a plain hotdog. I retraced my steps back upstairs to eat with my parents. The cashiers upstairs charged my parents for the hotdog. I hate to think how many times I dropped the hotdog on the floor and picked it up! I wish I remembered the name of the black male cook who operated the microwave in the grill. He was so kind to me. And this was the first microwave I remember seeing. This was about 1958-1960.

column4: Disappointed in the timing of this post. It may have been a preset post::: but ill timing after last night and should have been caught and deleted for the time being. I am an alum of this university and expect better for this student and all students. He was using the crosswalk properly. An unlit::: barely visible crosswalk after dark on a busy road. And yes::: he looked both ways! Maybe teach drivers what to do when approaching a crosswalk? And make them more visible at night!
column5: Shame on you::: Mississippi State University. Warn your drivers about pedestrians. Enforce speed limits::: have campus police reinforce those signs. Add speed bumps. Your DRIVERS and poorly enforced road signs are the problem. Do better. You will see change.

â€œGrowing up in New Orleans::: one thing that caught my eye a lot was the large twin bridges that cross Lake Pontchartrain. column1: Do you know Colvard? On the first day of class::: most new and returning students walk through or past MSUâ€™s central building::: Colvard Student Union. Built in 1964 and renovated in 2008::: it becomes a familiar site for those searching out food::: coffee and student-focused offices such as the Center for Student Activities and the Holmes Cultural Diversity Center. #WeRingTrue
column3: Dr. Dean Colvard was the President of MSU beginning in 1960 and was President when I graduated in 1962. Dr. Ben Hilbun was President when I entered the University in 1958. Our class was the first freshman class under the new name::: Mississippi State University. Dr. Colvard helped MSU make great strides and was greatly admired and respected by the faculty and students. His leadership was essential in moving MSU toward an inclusive and outstanding University.  The Colvard Student Union is built on part of the site of Old Main Dormatory::: which burned in 1959. The dormatory footprint extended to about the Mongomery Building::: and was reportedly the largest in the US. I was rooming there::: in an area known as Polecat Alley::: when the building burned.
column4: It had the best coffee shop in the eighties. I still crave those donuts ğŸ©
column5: It had just opened when we moved back to Starkville in 1964. As children::: we loved the bowling alley and the cafeteria. As a teenager::: I saw many an art show in the gallery. We also saw movies and heard many diverse speakers in the auditorium. We also found the underground passageway from the Union to the cafeteria where we would race the food services carts. Happy memories...
column7: In the mid 70s there was a hippie table on the east side of the dining hall... Happy memories there. Tea was 15 cents and crackers were free. A grilled cheese was a buck with no charge for pickles.
column8: Changed a lot.... John Prine played on that porch in 1976
column9: Wish I knew Colvard. It was not there when I graduated in '61.
column10: In 1972 I played a lot of billiards and bowled downstairs and for money's sake I learned to like rice and gravy.
column11: I worked in the Union as a student and used to lock it up at night!
column12: I see students sitting around tables. We use to sit around on the bullring back in '56. It has really changed since then!
column13: When I was there in 2000-2001::: you went there to eat Chick-Fil-A if you had time to wait in line and Chinese food if you wanted to eat quickly and get out. Wendy's was generally somewhere in the middle....haha

column1: â€œMy interest in public health started in high school and has continued to grow through my coursework at Mississippi State. In addition to being a microbiology major::: I am completing a medical humanities certificate at MSU::: which has helped me learn about the social aspects of medicine and their effects on health and disease. This past spring::: I took two classes that focused on public health. What I learned ignited a huge passion and allowed me to see the intersection between primary care and public health. My hope is to be a primary care physician and conduct clinical research to look into the best approaches for preventative medicine while serving as a leader and community health resource within that role. My professors at MSU have really impacted my path and have helped me realize there is a place for what I want to do. For the first time in my life::: Iâ€™m able to say exactly what that is::: and being able to get that confirmation and clarity from my professors has been really special.â€ Maggie Shepherd::: Microbiology::: Senior #MSUExperience

column1: Let the orientation sessions begin! Mississippi State is welcoming the class of 2025 with big smiles and summer fun. #WeRingTrue
column3: So happy for these new freshman. Really::: I am. Unfortunately nothing has been done for the class that lost their senior year of high school AND their Freshman year of college. Sure would have been nice if there had been some kind of ceremony::: some kind of â€œanythingâ€ to make up for it. There was no welcome. No fanfare. No fun. Pretty much little to no games to attend::: no meetings::: No meeting new people in the dorm::: no excitement. No::: you made it through this less than spectacular year. Nothing. Well::: some::: like my son::: did get to experience two weeks of quarantine at the local hotel. ğŸ˜–Just something that said â€œWe see you and we recognize your sacrifice and this is just for you::: Class of 2024.â€ This is a sentiment expressed by many parents on our MSU parents group lately as we see the excitement and preparations for this yearâ€™s Freshman class. It hurts. Hereâ€™s to you Class of 2024. We saw your struggle::: I saw my sonâ€™s struggle::: and thankfully most of you made it through the year. Wish I could do something special for you. Iâ€™m hoping that you get to see what a real college experience is like this year. Hopefully you get a chance to yell Hail State! And yes::: I hope I get to see you experience it too. It hasnâ€™t been fun as parents either. ğŸ˜– Big disappointment for us too. Once again::: so happy for the freshman this year. It really sounds exciting to be starting college the way it should be.

column1: â€œThe Complete 2 Compete (C2C) program at MSU is an amazing opportunity for those who attended college but didnâ€™t finish because life got in the way. I joined the National Guard 16 years ago and attended MSU for two years. However::: I got deployed in 2009 and never went back to school. Now::: the C2C program is giving me the chance to finish what I started. The combination of hours from MSU::: ECCC and the National Guard is actually enough to complete my degree without any additional coursework. Not only will this degree help me throughout my military career and provide an opportunity for a promotion sooner::: but it also sets an example for my children. When I walk at graduation this week::: I want my kids to see how important it is to complete what you started.â€ Robert Oswalt::: University Studies::: Complete 2 Compete #MSUExperience

column1: â€œOne aspect that makes our forestry program so unique is the access we have to hands-on learning opportunities. column1: #CelebrateFirstGen MSU Asst. Director for Disability Support Services Bret Varner had an unusual journey to earning his bachelorâ€™s degree. He uses the lessons he learned to help the first-generation students he encounters. Take a look!

#CelebrateFirstGen â€œAs a first-generation student::: my journey at MSU has been a rollercoaster ride as I have experienced multiple emotions while transitioning from high school to college. I've felt anxiety::: confusion::: fear of not being successful::: the pressure of being financially responsible for everything::: and most importantly::: there were times where I've felt alone. However::: I was never alone. Other first-generation students and staff offered their support and helped me balance my social life::: academics::: work::: and family. I was introduced to campus resources beneficial navigating college::: such as advising programs::: tutoring programs::: financial aid programs::: and the counseling center. Being a first-generation student comes with a lot of responsibility. I must help pay for my education::: more so than students of higher socioeconomic background. Nonetheless::: I feel a sense of pride in being the first in my family to attend college. I know that a college degree can be the key to many opportunities in the future.â€ -Myesha Stovall

column4: In my MSU senior year::: 1962::: as an accounting major::: I took a class entitled "Electronic Data Processing" taught by a professor::: whose name escapes me. In general it was an introductory class regarding punched cards and how alpha and numerical characters could be translated/ punched into an 80 column card::: which could then be 'read' by a computer. At that time I had no earthly idea that within six months I would begin a twelve year career as a systems analyst/ computer programmer at Union Planters National Bank in Memphis. Three other guys and I spent the next six years converting the banks accounting and management systems from manual to automated. Our computer was the first one developed by IMB (1401 with 8:::000 bytes of internal storage plus input/output of card and reel tapes) for commercial accounting use. My final six years::: before seminary::: were spent establishing a new department (Computer Services) which would provide those same automated services to smaller banks all across the mid-south area. In time we had two satellite centers....one in Grenada::: Ms. and the other in Jackson::: Tn. The above is exciting news and demonstrates how MSU continues to be a leading force for the betterment of Mississippi. We've come a long way::: Bulldogs!

column1: â€œI first got interested in nutrition by watching YouTube health videos. My program is also preparing me for the medical field::: and itâ€™s been exciting to see how my interests in nutrition and medicine intertwine. As part of that program::: I go to the UMC campus regularly for medical experience. They assess what weâ€™ve been learning::: and I always feel equipped with the right answers::: which shows that MSU is truly preparing me and teaching me what I need to learn.â€  Tyus Wilson::: Senior::: Food Science::: Nutrition and Health Promotion #MSUExperience
